abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Second Community
            Forestry Project is to assist indigenous communities, and
            "ejidos" in selected Mexican States, strengthen
            community ties, better manage their forest resources,
            diversify forest-based production, create and strengthen
            community enterprises, and increase their income. This would
            be achieved by making private-sector and technical
            assistance available to communities that own economically,
            valuable forest lands, to help them manage their forest
            resources in an ecologically, and financially sustainable
            fashion. To this end, this initial environmental management
            plan stipulates that any forest management initiative
            supported by the project, should demonstrate compliance with
            the environmental laws and regulations in Mexico, and
            further specifies recognition of, and respect owed for any
            legally documented, or customary land tenure and user
            rights, as well as the rights of indigenous peoples, ethnic
            groups, and workers. Mitigation measures are addressed as
            follows. Areas larger than twenty hectares shall require a
            simplified forest management plan, underlining that species
            listed as endangered, should only be utilized under the
            supervision of an established Environmental Management Unit.
            Consequently, following a consultation process,
            participatory forest management plans will be established in
            accordance with stakeholders, communities, and local
            governments. Subprojects will be subject to a screening
            process, to evaluate potential adverse environmental
            impacts, benefits or risks, prior to project appraisal.
            Specific mitigation measures shall apply to areas of steep
            slopes, of potential soil erosion, to riverine areas, and to
            harvesting methods, as well as construction of forest roads.
            Commercial harvesting operations will only be financed when
            affected areas are not critical forests, or critical natural
            habitats, and, certified by an independent forest authority.
            Certification, though not legally required, will be
            supported through the National Forest Fund.
